dataObjects.title: IUCN Red List Assessment
dataObjects.rights: © International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.rightsHolder: International Union for Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: De Grave, S. & Mantellato, F. 2013. Atya gabonensis. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description:
Red List Category
LC
Least Concern

Red List Criteria

Version
3.1

Year Assessed
2013

Assessor/s
De Grave, S. & Mantellato, F.

Reviewer/s
Cumberlidge, N. & Smith, K.

Contributor/s

Justification
This species is amphi-atlantic, occurring from the Democratic Republic of Congo through to Senegal, as well as in Venezuela, Suriname and Brazil. However the South American populations may pertain to Atya scabra (Mantelatto, F.L. pers. comm. 2012) and no recent records are known in South America. It occurs in larger lowland rivers, often with fast currents and on a rocky substrate. This is considered a widespread species with no known major threats, as such it is considered as Least Concern. Even if the South American populations are excluded, the species would still qualify as Least Concern.

dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: De Grave, S. & Mantellato, F. 2013. Atya gabonensis. In: IUCN 2014 . IUCN Red List of Threatened Species. Version 2014.1 . <www.iucnredlist.org>
dataObjects.description:
Population
The species (if viable) occurs in very low population numbers in South America (Mantelatto, F.L. pers. comm. 2012). There have been no records of this species in South America for the past 15 years. In West Africa, the species is considered to be relatively abundant.

Population Trend
Unknown

dataObjects.subject: http://www.eol.org/voc/table_of_contents#Wikipedia
dataObjects.title: Atya gabonensis
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: "Atya gabonensis." Wikipedia, The Free Encyclopedia. 3 Sep 2013, 20:22 UTC. 22 Oct 2013 <http://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Atya_gabonensis&oldid=574589387>.
dataObjects.description:
Atya gabonensis (vampire shrimp) is a species of freshwater shrimp from West Africa and South America. It is an omnivorous filter feeder that uses feather-like claspers to filter particles from the water. It can grow to 6 inches (150 mm).

Contents

  • 1 Distribution
  • 2 In aquaria
  • 3 References
  • 4 External links

Distribution[edit]

Atya gabonensis is found in West Africa, from Senegal to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, and in South America from Venezuela to Brazil.[2]

Atya gabonensis

In aquaria[edit]

Despite their predatory-sounding name, they are a non-aggressive species that does well in community tanks that have areas to hide during the molting process. Another requirement is a moderate to strong current where the shrimp can sit and catch food. A pH of 6.5–7.8 is acceptable as well as temperatures of 74–84 °F (23–29 °C). As with most invertebrates they are very susceptible to medications used to treat many fish diseases, with copper being deadly. Also ammonia and nitrite poisoning are possible.[3]

Coloring of this species can vary from a creamy white to an almost rusty brown, and also a deep blue. It is believed that the water conditions will affect coloring and harder water causes the blue morph. These shrimp have been known to change coloring several times in the same year.[3]

References[edit]

  1. ^ Charles Fransen (2012). "Atya gabonensis Giebel, 1875". World Register of Marine Species. Retrieved October 29, 2012. 
  2. ^ Horton H. Hobbs, Jr. & C. W. Hart, Jr. (1982). "The shrimp genus Atya (Decapoda: Atyidae)". Smithsonian Contributions to Zoology 364: 143 pp. hdl:10088/5544. 
  3. ^ a b "Vampire Shrimp". Aquatic Community. Retrieved 2012-08-11.
